pullRequest.body:
+ Create a new file for materials about bivariate polynomials developed using `R[X][X]` rather than `MvPolynomial`. Introduce `evalEval` for evaluation at a point (x,y) on the plane, and use it in Affine.lean and Jacobian.lean.

+ Move the notations `R[X][Y]` and `Y` from `EllipticCurve/Afffine.lean` to the new file.

+ Add two lemmas in `Affine.lean` that relates `negPolynomial` and `polynomialY`, and two trivial lemmas `some_ne_zero` and `some_eq_some_iff`.

+ Prove two affine formulas `addX_eq_subX_sub` and `addY_sub_negY` which are crucial for the development of division polynomials.

+ Golf the definition of addition of rational points and subsequent lemmas, including two proofs in `Group.lean`.

+ Remove `eval_polynomial(X,Y)` lemmas in favor of bivariate polynomial lemma `map_mapRingHom_eval_map_eval`; add a lemma `Equation.map`.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

### PR summary [e91c8ada02](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/13845/commits/e91c8ada02e913f78814ef6f1749e14a5151bfce)

#### Import changes

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.AlgebraicGeometry.EllipticCurve.Affine | 1014 | 1179 | +165 (+16.27%) |
| Mathlib.AlgebraicGeometry.EllipticCurve.Jacobian | 1026 | 1184 | +158 (+15.40%) |

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Equation.map`
`+ Y_sub_negPolynomial`
`+ Y_sub_polynomialY`
`+ addX_eq_addX_negY_sub`
`+ addY_sub_negY_addY`
`+ coe_algebraMap_eq_CC`
`+ coe_evalEvalRingHom`
`+ cyclic_sum_Y_mul_X_sub_X`
`+ evalEval`
`+ evalEvalRingHom_eq`
`+ evalEval_C`
`+ evalEval_X`
`+ evalEval_baseChange_polynomial_X_Y`
`+ evalEval_mk`
`+ evalEval_polynomial`
`+ evalEval_polynomialX`
`+ evalEval_polynomialX_zero`
`+ evalEval_polynomialY`
`+ evalEval_polynomialY_zero`
`+ evalEval_polynomial_zero`
`+ eval_C_X_comp_eval₂_map_C_X`
`+ eval_C_X_eval₂_map_C_X`
`+ eval₂RingHom_eval₂RingHom`
`+ eval₂_evalRingHom`
`+ eval₂_eval₂RingHom_apply`
`+ map_evalRingHom_eval`
`+ map_mapRingHom_evalEval`
`+ map_mapRingHom_eval_map`
`+ map_mapRingHom_eval_map_eval`
`+ some_ne_zero`
`- baseChange_eval_polynomial`
`- baseChange_eval_polynomialX`
`- baseChange_eval_polynomialY`
`- map_eval_polynomial`
`- map_eval_polynomialX`
`- map_eval_polynomialY`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh short <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh <optional_commit>
```
</details>

</details>
Could you make sure it's clear from the PR title that this PR is mostly about bivariate polynomials? I'm sure most people will not look further if they think it's about elliptic curves.

In my refactored `universal` branch I have this for CoordinateRing:
```
variable {W} {x y : R} (eqn : W.Equation x y)

noncomputable def eval : W.CoordinateRing →+* R :=
  AdjoinRoot.lift (evalRingHom x) y <| by rwa [eval₂_evalRingHom]

lemma eval_mk (p : R[X][Y]) : eval eqn (mk _ p) = p.evalEval x y := by
  rw [← eval₂_evalRingHom]; exact AdjoinRoot.lift_mk _ p
```
Your version is more general and could fit in the Bivariate file (maybe with import AdjoinRoot added).

:v: alreadydone can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9677744674/job/26700056466)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9677744674/job/26700056218)
Looks fine, but what's the plan for when you start wanting trivariate polynomials? create a `PolynomialPolynomialPolynomial` scope?

Thanks for the review!

> Looks fine, but what's the plan for when you start wanting trivariate polynomials? create a `PolynomialPolynomialPolynomial` scope?

As you can see, we use `MvPolynomial (Fin 3) R` in the Jacobian (and projective) APIs. The choice to use `R[X][Y]` here is because the Weierstrass polynomial is a nice monic quadratic polynomial in the second variable `Y`, making it convenient to show the Weierstrass polynomial is irreducible and compute norms in the CoordinateRing, and we rely on the `AdjoinRoot` API to define the CoordinateRing, etc. (Also, division polynomials are bivariate polynomials, but many of them have equivalent univariate forms, and it's easier to convert between R[X][Y] and R[X].)

We can't exclude the possibility that someone will need `R[X][Y][Z]` in the future, so it does look saner to rename `PolynomialPolynomial` to `Polynomial2` so we can have `Polynomial3` when necessary. If @Multramate agrees I'll make the change.

It's a pity that `eval₂` is taken so we have to go with `evalEval` ... Using `eval2` would be too confusing, I think.
Thanks! Here are some preliminary suggestions.
Here are some further comments on `Affine.lean`. I won't comment further on the changes for `Point.add` because I'll handle them in my chore PR.
I am happy with the changes in `AlgebraicGeometry/EllipticCurve`. I won't comment on `Algebra/Polynomial/Bivariate` as the naming is still up for discussion on Zulip.

It would be cool if we have some compatibility lemmas with `AdjoinRoot`:
```
variable {R : Type u} [CommRing R] {x y : R} {p : R[X][Y]} (h : p.evalEval x y = 0)

namespace AdjoinRoot

@[simps!]
def evalEval : AdjoinRoot p →+* R :=
  lift (evalRingHom x) y <| eval₂_evalRingHom x y p ▸ h

lemma evalEval_eq (g : R[X][Y]) : evalEval h (mk p g) = g.evalEval x y := by
  erw [AdjoinRoot.lift_mk, eval₂_evalRingHom]

end AdjoinRoot
```
Not quite sure where to add this though.

We seem to have a consensus that there are unsolved naming issues here but we haven't yet agreed on a solution.

However I don't think we need to hold up the whole PR until we figure this out since the current names are OK.

One minor suggestion but otherwise this LGTM.

bors d+
Shouldn't this statement also use `evalEval`?

The pattern of evalEval is `(W.polynomialY.eval (C y)).eval x` so this statement doesn't exactly match the pattern. (We do occasionally evaluate at something that is not `C y`, for example `linePolynomial`.) An `evalEval` version could be deduced from this, but I'd add it when it's actually needed.

Note: I'm not adding deprecated aliases because this was only added recently in #13356.

Actually, in the `universal` branch I'm now removing these lemmas in favor of bivariate polynomial lemmas
```
lemma map_mapRingHom_eval_map : (p.map <| mapRingHom f).eval (q.map f) = (p.eval q).map f

lemma map_mapRingHom_eval_map_eval (r : R) :
    ((p.map <| mapRingHom f).eval <| q.map f).eval (f r) = f ((p.eval q).eval r)

lemma map_mapRingHom_evalEval (x y : R) :
    (p.map <| mapRingHom f).evalEval (f x) (f y) = f (p.evalEval x y)
```
and this one too?
ditto

```suggestion
and the notation `Y` for the second variable, in the `Polynomial2` scope.
```
would be better maybe? It would match the existing `Sum3` scope which plays a similar role for `α ⊕ β ⊕ γ`.

I agree it's a good idea to rename (pending approval of @Multramate), though your analogy is not very exact (`Sum` only appears twice in `α ⊕ β ⊕ γ` so it could be appropriate to call it `Sum2` or `SumSum`).

I don't mind changing it to `Polynomial2` since `Sum3` exists. I would think it's unlikely that someone will create `R[X][Y][Z]` - I observed many months ago that working in this ring was really slow, but maybe that is a lot better now.
Ah, I just saw your other comment - now I think that we should definitely change `evalEval` to `eval2` if we want to change `PolynomialPolynomial` to `Polynomial2`....

Don't you find `eval2` too confusing given [Polynomial.eval₂](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Polynomial/Eval.html#Polynomial.eval%E2%82%82)? Should we change `Polynomial2` back then @YaelDillies? Or should we make a poll on Zulip ...
I guess we could also just put the notations under the Polynomial scope ...
Maybe make a poll on Zulip, yeah
`let`?
I think I do want to inline this expression; it's just it appears multiple times so I'd like a shorthand. Without `letI` maybe there'll be issues rewriting with it, I'm not sure.

Rewriting seems to be fine with `let`:
```
example : y₁ * (x₂ - W.addX x₁ x₂ (W.slope x₁ x₂ y₁ y₂)) +
    y₂ * (W.addX x₁ x₂ (W.slope x₁ x₂ y₁ y₂) - x₁) +
    W.negAddY x₁ x₂ y₁ (W.slope x₁ x₂ y₁ y₂) * (x₁ - x₂) = 0 := by
  rw [cyclic_sum_Y_mul_X_sub_X _ _ hx]
```
I still don't see the need for inlining in any situation.
Thanks for testing! Removed the `I`
I don't like this name, because `subX` isn't a thing. We either should make that a thing, or change this to `addX_sub_addX_negY_sub` (and I don't know what to call the rest).

I renamed this lemma and the last one in https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/13845/commits/2d333ea40f58745d5aa4c5c999f24a5ba72990b8 but leave the `cyclic_sum` one unchanged.

I think I answered all questions; thanks for the review!

You beat me to it! [Here is my incomplete branch](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/compare/EllipticCurve.Chore) that does some of the golfing for affine point addition, but I haven't made a PR because I felt they were still somewhat inconsequential. Maybe you can have a look and get something out of it, and I'll update my branch with more chores in the future once this one is merged.

Thanks for sharing! In this PR I'm just golfing the definition and fixing things, so I basically only applied forced golfs, having no intention to make the diff larger. Once this PR is accepted, your further golf of the lemmas should be easy to merge!

Urgh, I just noticed that some of my `map` lemmas might not have the correct name: `map_*` should be a lemma of the form `f (...) = (f ...)`, but some of mine change the Weierstrass curve instead? I don't know what's the best naming convention, but maybe you can think of something that's analogous to the distinction between `Equation.map` and `map_polynomial_*`. Surely you should add the analogue of all of the new additions for `Nonsingular` too...

As I remarked [in the Jacobian lemmas PR](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/13846#discussion_r1641567888), the other naming convention is also common, e.g. in [Prod.map_injective](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Prod/Basic.html#Prod.map_injective) and many more `map_injective` lemmas. I think we can be satisfied with local consistency.

What do you want me to add about `Nonsingular`? `Nonsingular.map` isn't necessarily true for non-injective RingHom.
Fair enough!
Can we not get `some_eq_some_iff` from `ext` (as a tag in the structure or however else?)?

`@[ext]` before the definition `inductive Point` produces the error
```
@[ext] attribute only applies to structures or theorems proving x = y, got Type u
```
so I guess it's not yet supported. There's [Lean.Parser.Tactic.injection](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Init/Tactics.html#Lean.Parser.Tactic.injection) but it doesn't seem to shorten the proof.
I seem to recall that there's some `mk_inj` stuff (in Lean 3?) but I can't find it now.

Yes, this is just:
```
lemma some_eq_some_iff {x₁ x₂ y₁ y₂ : R} (h₁ : W.Nonsingular x₁ y₁) (h₂ : W.Nonsingular x₂ y₂) :
    some h₁ = some h₂ ↔ x₁ = x₂ ∧ y₁ = y₂ := by
  rw [some.injEq]
```
Now I don't think we need this lemma since we have `some.injEq`.
I think there might a couple of places in the files where I implicitly use `some_ne_zero`, but via the `contradiction` tactic instead. Can you check that these have all been changed?

It seems there are two appearances of `contradiction` in the `Affine` file; the appearance of `any_goals contradiction` in `map_injective` can be replaced but would make the proof longer, so I'd rather leave it as is.

```suggestion
/-- The notation `Y` for `X` in the `Polynomial` scope. -/
```
same below

Let's change `eval_polynomialX_zero` to:
```
lemma eval_polynomialX_zero : W.polynomialX.evalEval 0 0 = -W.a₄ := by
  simp only [eval_polynomialX, zero_add, zero_sub, mul_zero, zero_pow two_ne_zero]
```
and `eval_polynomialY_zero` to:
```
lemma eval_polynomialY_zero : W.polynomialY.evalEval 0 0 = W.a₃ := by
  simp only [eval_polynomialY, zero_add, mul_zero]
```
Then this becomes:
```suggestion
  rw [Nonsingular, equation_zero, eval_polynomialX_zero, neg_ne_zero, eval_polynomialY_zero,
    or_comm]
```

By the way, it's possible to directly prove `nonsingular_of_Δ_ne_zero` using the following formulas that I got from Ayad's paper:

$\Delta = 4 (36 x^3 + 9 b_2  x^2 + (42 b_4 - b_2^2) x + 27 b_6 - b_2 b_4) F + (-48 x^2 - 8 b_2 x + (b_2^2 - 32 b_4)) \phi_2 - (-12 x^3 + b_2  x^2 + 10 b_4 x + 27 b_6 - b_2 b_4) F_Y^2$
and $\phi_2 = (b_2 + 12 x) F - (2 x + a_2) F_Y^2 - a_1  F_X F_Y + F_X^2$,

where $F, F_X$ and $F_Y=\psi_2$ are W.polynomial, W.polynomialX and W.polynomialY.

(not saying we should replace the proof though)

Let's change `eval_polynomial_zero` to:
```
lemma eval_polynomial_zero : W.polynomial.evalEval 0 0 = -W.a₆ := by
  simp only [eval_polynomial, zero_add, zero_sub, mul_zero, zero_pow <| Nat.succ_ne_zero _]
```
Then this becomes:
```suggestion
  rw [Equation, eval_polynomial_zero, neg_eq_zero]
```
Should we change this (and friends) to `polynomial_eval` (or even `polynomial_evalEval`?), to match `map_polynomial_eval` (and friends)
Good idea, changed to `polynomial_evalEval_*` and added deprecation.
I won't touch the Jacobian and Projective files in this PR though, other than necessary fixes.

Could you remind me why we prefer `polynomial_eval` over `eval_polynomial`? With dot notation we have `monic_polynomial` for `W.polynomial.Monic` but `polynomial_eval ...` for `W.polynomial.eval ...`.

Good point. Originally I renamed `map_eval_polynomial` to `map_polynomial_eval` because the `map_*` lemmas (including auto-generated `map_a₁`) follows the inside-first, outside-last convention, so it's natural to rename `eval_polynomial` to `polynomial_eval` too. However, I've now removed `map_eval_polynomial`, so we don't have to stick to that convention when it comes to `polynomial` and it's better to follow the `monic`, `degree` lemmas etc. I'm going to rename to `evalEval_polynomial_*`.
Thanks, and sorry for going back and forth!
This isn't really Lean code - can we instead write it (and the ones below) in LaTeX?

I find this more readable (in VS Code), so I switched from LaTeX to Unicode. I can remove the backticks if you prefer. (I know that backticks can are intended for code blocks in markdown but sometimes I just want to use it for the highlighted monospace style to highlight a formula, not necessarily code.)

I would argue that ultimately we want equations to be rendered best in mathlib4_docs. Personally I don't look at the code for equations, otherwise my module docstrings in e.g. `DivisionPolynomial/Basic` would be a huge mess.

LaTeX won't render when you hover your mouse over the name of the lemma ...
This will still be pretty readable in the mathlib4_docs IMO, so I think it's a good compromise ...

Let's use the `slope` API:
```suggestion
  simp_rw [slope_of_X_ne hx, addX, negY, ← neg_sub x₁, neg_sq]
  field_simp [sub_ne_zero.mpr hx]
  ring1
```
Arguably we should have `negY_of_*` and `addX/Y_of_*` mirroring those for Jacobian coordinates... Maybe I'll add them another day and that could simplify this proof without the need for `field_simp`.

Ditto:
```suggestion
  simp_rw [slope_of_X_ne hx, negAddY, addX]
  field_simp [sub_ne_zero.mpr hx]
  ring1
```

Spacing:
```suggestion
/-- The formula `ψ(P₁ + P₂) = (ψ(P₂)(x(P₁) - x(P₃)) - ψ(P₁)(x(P₂) - x(P₃))) / (x(P₂) - x(P₁))`,
where `ψ(x,y) = 2y + a₁x + a₃`. -/
```
Again maybe we LaTeX this?

```suggestion
  linear_combination 2 * cyclic_sum_Y_mul_X_sub_X y₁ y₂ hx
```
`baseChange_evalEval_polynomial`? Put this together with the other baseChange lemmas?
I think `evalEval_baseChange_polynomial_X_Y` is better ...

I'm not sure I should put it with other `baseChange` lemmas, since they're about general base changes but this is about a very specific one. I prefer to make it available immediately after its depency `map_polynomial` is proved.
Yeah, fair enough!

Wouldn't this be more natural of a direction to state?
```
example (x y : R) (p : R[X][Y]) : p.evalEval x y = (p.map <| evalRingHom x).eval y
```
This says evaluating `p` at `y` then at `x` is the same as evaluating `p` at `x` then at `y`.
Maybe this could be `evalEval_comm` or `evalEval_eq`, or `map_evalRingHom_eval` if it's reversed.
I guess there's no harm in having both. You can replace the `rfl` with a rewrite of `coe_eval₂RingHom` too.
I added your version, which just differ by a `Polynomial.eval_map`. I consider `evalEval` to be the simp normal form so I put it on the RHS.
Thanks!

Can you add this somewhere?
```
lemma evalEval_C (p : R[X]) : (C p).evalEval x y = p.eval x := by
  rw [evalEval, eval_C]
```
Thanks!

And since we have this, why don't we add this too:
```
lemma evalEval_X : X.evalEval x y = y := by
  rw [evalEval, eval_X, eval_C]
```
We can try to mimic the API for normal `eval` and see which are relevant to `evalEval`.

```suggestion
    letI x₃ := W.addX x₁ x₂ (W.slope x₁ x₂ y₁ y₂)
```

Thanks for the approval! I actually originally started with `letI`, but after @Multramate [showed](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/13845#discussion_r1644509949) that the lemmas are still good for rewrites even with `let`, I switched by his request. Do you still prefer `letI` given that `let` works?
I still prefer `letI` but no objection if you want to stick with `let`.

I'm fine with `letI` (since I don't want to bother Junyan a third time), but I'm still very unconvinced about its use case. Is there a scenario where `letI` works but `let` definitely doesn't? It seems to me they're doing exactly the same thing.

```suggestion
    letI x₃ := W.addX x₁ x₂ (W.slope x₁ x₂ y₁ y₂)
    letI y₃ := W.addY x₁ x₂ y₁ (W.slope x₁ x₂ y₁ y₂)
```

We should add the behaviour of evaluations over the usual operations in a separate PR. Here are some to begin with (because it seems that these are the only ones I need):
```
lemma evalEval_add {R : Type u} [Semiring R] (x y : R) (p q : R[X][Y]) :
    (p + q).evalEval x y = p.evalEval x y + q.evalEval x y := by
  simp only [evalEval, eval_add]

lemma evalEval_sub {R : Type u} [Ring R] (x y : R) (p q : R[X][Y]) :
    (p - q).evalEval x y = p.evalEval x y - q.evalEval x y := by
  simp only [evalEval, eval_sub]

lemma evalEval_mul {R : Type u} [CommSemiring R] (x y : R) (p q : R[X][Y]) :
    (p * q).evalEval x y = p.evalEval x y * q.evalEval x y := by
  simp only [evalEval, eval_mul]

lemma evalEval_pow {R : Type u} [CommSemiring R] (x y : R) (p : R[X][Y]) (n : ℕ) :
    (p ^ n).evalEval x y = p.evalEval x y ^ n := by
  simp only [evalEval, eval_pow]
```
You can also get these by rw [<- evalEvalRingHom] and then use the generic map_* lemmas ...
Yes, but they're very convenient to have
If you do want them you can submit a PR and see how it goes.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(EllipticCurve): affine formulas and bivariate polynomial lemmas

source.title: feat(EllipticCurve): ZSMul formula in terms of division polynomials

nodes.body: Looks fine, but what's the plan for when you start wanting trivariate polynomials? create a `PolynomialPolynomialPolynomial` scope?

Thanks for the review!

> Looks fine, but what's the plan for when you start wanting trivariate polynomials? create a `PolynomialPolynomialPolynomial` scope?

As you can see, we use `MvPolynomial (Fin 3) R` in the Jacobian (and projective) APIs. The choice to use `R[X][Y]` here is because the Weierstrass polynomial is a nice monic quadratic polynomial in the second variable `Y`, making it convenient to show the Weierstrass polynomial is irreducible and compute norms in the CoordinateRing, and we rely on the `AdjoinRoot` API to define the CoordinateRing, etc. (Also, division polynomials are bivariate polynomials, but many of them have equivalent univariate forms, and it's easier to convert between R[X][Y] and R[X].)

We can't exclude the possibility that someone will need `R[X][Y][Z]` in the future, so it does look saner to rename `PolynomialPolynomial` to `Polynomial2` so we can have `Polynomial3` when necessary. If @Multramate agrees I'll make the change.

It's a pity that `eval₂` is taken so we have to go with `evalEval` ... Using `eval2` would be too confusing, I think.
Thanks! Here are some preliminary suggestions.
Could you make sure it's clear from the PR title that this PR is mostly about bivariate polynomials? I'm sure most people will not look further if they think it's about elliptic curves.
Here are some further comments on `Affine.lean`. I won't comment further on the changes for `Point.add` because I'll handle them in my chore PR.
I am happy with the changes in `AlgebraicGeometry/EllipticCurve`. I won't comment on `Algebra/Polynomial/Bivariate` as the naming is still up for discussion on Zulip.

It would be cool if we have some compatibility lemmas with `AdjoinRoot`:
```
variable {R : Type u} [CommRing R] {x y : R} {p : R[X][Y]} (h : p.evalEval x y = 0)

namespace AdjoinRoot

@[simps!]
def evalEval : AdjoinRoot p →+* R :=
  lift (evalRingHom x) y <| eval₂_evalRingHom x y p ▸ h

lemma evalEval_eq (g : R[X][Y]) : evalEval h (mk p g) = g.evalEval x y := by
  erw [AdjoinRoot.lift_mk, eval₂_evalRingHom]

end AdjoinRoot
```
Not quite sure where to add this though.

In my refactored `universal` branch I have this for CoordinateRing:
```
variable {W} {x y : R} (eqn : W.Equation x y)

noncomputable def eval : W.CoordinateRing →+* R :=
  AdjoinRoot.lift (evalRingHom x) y <| by rwa [eval₂_evalRingHom]

lemma eval_mk (p : R[X][Y]) : eval eqn (mk _ p) = p.evalEval x y := by
  rw [← eval₂_evalRingHom]; exact AdjoinRoot.lift_mk _ p
```
Your version is more general and could fit in the Bivariate file (maybe with import AdjoinRoot added).

We seem to have a consensus that there are unsolved naming issues here but we haven't yet agreed on a solution.

However I don't think we need to hold up the whole PR until we figure this out since the current names are OK.

One minor suggestion but otherwise this LGTM.

bors d+

:v: alreadydone can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9677744674/job/26700056466)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9677744674/job/26700056218)
